channel.title: NYT > World

item.title: A Saudi Morals Enforcer Called for a More Liberal Islam. Then the Death Threats Began.
item.media:description: Saudi women standing on the opposite side of the hall from the men at the Amex Luxury Expo in Riyadh in March.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: A longtime morals enforcer began to question the rules. He told his story to a Times correspondent who spent weeks in Saudi Arabia trying to understand its hyper-conservative strain of Islam, which is often blamed for terrorism.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: U.S. Will Deploy 560 Troops to Iraq to Help Retake Mosul From ISIS
item.description: The announcement, made by Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter, is the latest escalation of America’s combat role in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Iranian Lawmakers’ Car Ambushed by Gunmen in Kurdish Region
item.description: The two men were wounded, and the vehicle’s driver and a veterinarian traveling with them were killed, in an attack near Dalahu on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Cambodian Opposition Figure’s Killing Recalls Darker Times
item.media:description: Kem Ley had recently helped found a new political party in Cambodia.
item.description: Kem Ley, a prominent commentator who recently helped found a political party, was gunned down Sunday at a gas station in the capital.
item.dc:creator: JULIA WALLACE

item.title: Japan Election, a Landslide for Abe, Could Allow a Bolder Military
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan at the headquarters of the Liberal Democratic Party in Tokyo on Sunday. His party’s victory could allow Mr. Abe to realize his long-held ambition of revising the Constitution, which strictly limits the role of the military.
item.description: Voters have strengthened the hand of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who wants to revise the pacifist Constitution — a prospect likely to add to regional tensions.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: South Sudan Slides Closer to War as Gunfire Rumbles in Its Capital
item.media:description: A camp for displaced people in the Tomping area of Juba, South Sudan, on Monday. Fighting overshadowed the country’s fifth anniversary this weekend.
item.media:credit: Beatrice Mategwa/U.N. Mission in South Sudan, via Associated Press
item.description: Two United Nations peacekeepers were killed, and worries grew about attempts to kill civilians trapped in crowded displaced persons camps.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Malcolm Turnbull Claims Victory in Australia Election After Rival Concedes
item.description: The electoral commission has forecast that Mr. Turnbull’s Liberal Party-led coalition could win a combined 76 seats, which would give it an absolute majority.
item.dc:creator: BRETT COLE

item.title: Memo From Istanbul: As Erdogan Sculpts New Turkish Identity, Turks Look at His Work With Unease
item.media:description: A waiter at a nearly empty restaurant in Istanbul last month. Bomb attacks in the city have dissuaded tourists from visiting.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: While the nation contends with an uptick in violence and an increasingly autocratic leader, it also faces existential questions.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: Theresa May Poised to Be Britain’s Next Premier as Andrea Leadsom Quits Race
item.media:description: Home Secretary Theresa May campaigning in Birmingham, England, on Monday. She is expected to be the first female prime minister of Britain since Margaret Thatcher.
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron said the handover of power would be completed by Wednesday evening, and there appeared to be no hurdles to her ascension.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: South Africa Charges Twins Over Plot to Attack U.S. Embassy and Join ISIS
item.description: The brothers planned to attack the mission in Pretoria, as well as an unidentified “Jewish building” in the country, officials said.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Hong Kong Searches for a Culprit as Garbage Piles High on Beaches
item.media:description: City workers and residents cleaning up trash along Hong Kong’s shore. The city’s chief executive has laid much of the blame on mainland Chinese sources.
item.description: The labels and packaging in the debris suggest that much of it is originating in mainland China.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Shabab Stage Deadly Attack on Military Base in Somalia
item.description: At least five soldiers were killed in the assault about 30 miles outside the capital, Mogadishu, officials and witnesses said.
item.dc:creator: HUSSEIN MOHAMED

item.title: North Korea Cuts Off Only Diplomatic Channel With U.S. Over Sanctions
item.media:description: The leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-un, center, at the mausoleum in Pyongyang containing the remains of Mr. Kim’s father, Kim Jong-il, and grandfather, Kim Il-sung.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Reuters
item.description: Although the two countries have no diplomatic ties, North Korea’s United Nations mission had long served as a point of contact.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: France Loses a Soccer Championship, but Achieves a Rare Unity
item.media:description: Soccer fans in Bordeaux, France, after the final between France and Portugal in the European Championships on Sunday.
item.description: Despite a loss, France saw the finals of the European Championships as an opportunity to unite and recover after a difficult and divisive year.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Death Toll Rises in Jammu and Kashmir During Protests Over Separatist’s Death
item.media:description: Protesters clashed with the police in Srinagar on Sunday. Demonstrations began Saturday after security forces killed a separatist militant commander.
item.description: Two days of clashes between protesters and the police in Kashmir have resulted in at least 19 deaths and overwhelmed hospitals with the injured.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Berlin Protests in Support of Squatters Turn Violent
item.media:description: Police officers gathered near a housing complex on Rigaer Street, where a demonstration of squatters and their supporters erupted into what the police called the most violent protest in years, in Berlin on Saturday.
item.description: A demonstration on Saturday swelled to 3,500 people, and some threw rocks and bottles at police officers, who responded with tear gas and billy clubs.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Honoring García Lorca’s Genius: A Bout Over a $22 Million Archive
item.media:description: The entrance of the García Lorca Center in Granada, Spain.
item.media:credit: Laura Leon for The New York Times
item.description: An arts center first conceived in 2004 sits empty in Granada, Spain, while Federico García Lorca’s family members fight for control.
item.dc:creator: DOREEN CARVAJAL

item.title: News Analysis: Obama on ‘Brooding’ Over the Interminable Wars of His Presidency
item.media:description: President Barack Obama toured the Ross, a United States guided-missile destroyer, at the naval air station in Rota, Spain, on Sunday.
item.description: “What I’ve been trying to do is to create an architecture, a structure,” for an American approach to military operations, the president said, “and it’s not there yet.”
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Sinosphere: Hillary Clinton, as Seen Through a Chinese Prism
item.media:description: Hillary Clinton, then United State secretary of state, with Xi Jinping, China’s vice president at the time, at the Diaoyutai Guesthouse in Beijing on May 3, 2012.
item.description: Opinions on the American presidential candidate veer from admiration, mostly among women and civil libertarians, to distaste, mostly among male policy makers.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Beijing Zhongze Women's Legal Counseling and Service Center

item.title: Yemeni Guantánamo Prisoner Is Transferred to Italy After 14 Years
item.media:description: The prisoner population at Guantánamo Bay was reduced to no more than 78 with the latest release.
item.description: The latest transfer from the military prison came at a time of heightened scrutiny after a former prisoner there disappeared after being resettled in Uruguay.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Egyptian Minister Visits Israel in Push for Peace With Palestinians
item.description: In the first such high-level visit in nearly a decade, Sameh Shoukry, Egypt’s foreign minister, arrived in Israel to help rejuvenate the moribund peace process.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Japan Vote Strengthens Shinzo Abe’s Goal to Change Constitution
item.description: Whether Prime Minister Abe will be able to pursue his ambition of overturning the clause that calls for the complete renunciation of war remains to be seen.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Philippines v. China: Q. and A. on South China Sea Court Case
item.media:description: The Chinese Coast Guard confronted Filipino fishermen near Scarborough Shoal in the South China Sea last year.
item.description: An international court is scheduled to release a landmark ruling Tuesday on Beijing’s claim to sovereignty over 90 percent of the South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Juba Gripped by Renewed Violence as Factions Clash in South Sudan
item.description: Armed battles and waves of gunfire spread across the capital a day after the fifth anniversary of the nation’s independence.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN and JOSH KRON
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Story of Philistines Could Be Reshaped by Ancient Cemetery
item.media:description: Excavation of a possible Philistine cemetery in Israel by the Leon Levy Expedition to Ashkelon, one of the five ancient Philistine capitals.
item.media:credit: Tsafrir Abayov for the Leon Levy Expedition to Ashkelon
item.description: Archaeologists in Ashkelon, Israel, said they had found a burial site that could help reveal the origin and lifestyle of a civilization whose history has been written by its enemies.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: What in the World: Kenya Mocks Its Woes in Wry Verbal Shorthand
item.description: The country’s understated humor comes through in popular Swahili and English euphemisms for life’s annoyances and sins.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: What in the World: A Fire Monkey Can Usher In Chaos. So Can 600 or So Macaques.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Leif Parsons; Photo by Ben Sklar for The New York Times, Eric Thayer/Reuters
item.description: This is a rare Year of the Fire Monkey, an occasion often associated with chaos. Just ask a village in China that’s been overrun by little, loud primates.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: What in the World: Bulgarians Hope Che Guevara and Brigitte Bardot Can Save Their Village
item.media:description: Stefana Gospodinova and her mule with murals of themselves and Brigitte Bardot, a well-known animal lover, in the Bulgarian village of Staro Zhelezare.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Two artists want their murals of famous people — alongside portraits of residents — to help start a revival in Staro Zhelezare, population 400.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: Reporter’s Notebook: China’s Menacing Words for a Boat in Disputed Waters: ‘Get Out!’
item.media:description: A Chinese Coast Guard ship raced last month to intercept a boat carrying a reporter and photographer for The New York Times near Scarborough Shoal in the disputed South China Sea.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: A reporter who set out to see Scarborough Shoal in the disputed South China Sea found his boat quickly intercepted by the Chinese Coast Guard.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Editorial: Neighbors Stand Up to Venezuela
item.media:description: Nicolas Maduro, president of Venezuela, at a military parade earlier this week.
item.description: Latin American leaders are starting to take a harder line against President Nicolás Maduro, at long last.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Opinion: Why the E.U. Had It Coming
item.description: Frustration with the European Union has been building for decades.
item.dc:creator: TIM PARKS

item.title: Insider Podcasts: Gone: Global Warming Claims a Lake — and a Way of Life
item.media:description: The dry bed of Lake Poopó near Llapallapani.
item.description: The Andes bureau chief, Nicholas Casey, and the staff photographer Josh Haner give listeners a behind-the-scenes account of their article about a vanished lake.
item.dc:creator: SUSAN LEHMAN

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
